title: Airport Rush
description: Your flight is delayed, you're stressed, and you absolutely must complete some urgent work. The airport has multiple Wi-Fi options, but time pressure is making you consider cutting corners.

scenes.title: Flight Delayed
scenes.description: Your flight has been delayed by 2 hours. You're exhausted, stressed, and your phone is at 15% battery. Your boss just messaged that the client contract needs your signature TODAY, and there's a deadline in 45 minutes. You find a seat near an outlet.

scenes.title: Airport Networks
scenes.description: Your laptop shows multiple networks. You're stressed about the deadline. There's an airport info kiosk nearby, but there's a line.

networks.description: Official airport network - open with captive portal
Similar name but with hyphen and different suffix
Your phone's personal hotspot - uses cellular data

actions.label: Wait in line at info kiosk to verify

consequence.title: Excellent Decision Under Pressure
consequence.whatHappened: Despite the stress and time pressure, you chose to use your mobile data hotspot instead of any airport Wi-Fi. This is the most secure option available to you.
consequence.whyRisky: This was the ideal choice, and here's why it matters so much: Your mobile data connection goes directly from your phone to your carrier's cell tower using encrypted cellular protocols. There is no shared local network for attackers to exploit. No evil twins, no man-in-the-middle attacks, no packet sniffing - the attack surface that exists on Wi-Fi simply doesn't exist on cellular. For urgent, high-stakes work like signing contracts, mobile data is almost always the right answer.
consequence.saferAlternative: You made the optimal choice. The only consideration is data usage if you're on a limited plan, but for signing a critical contract, the peace of mind is worth any potential overage charges. Security over convenience, always.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Cellular networks use strong encryption between your device and the cell tower, and the connection is point-to-point rather than broadcast like Wi-Fi. An attacker would need extremely expensive equipment and significant expertise to intercept cellular traffic, compared to the $50 laptop setup that works for Wi-Fi attacks.

actions.label: Call client to request deadline extension anyway

scenes.title: Secure Mobile Signature
scenes.description: You signed the contract on your mobile data connection...

consequence.title: Contract Signed Securely
consequence.whatHappened: You signed the legally binding contract while connected through your mobile data. This bypassed all the risks associated with airport Wi-Fi networks entirely.
consequence.whyRisky: There's minimal risk here. Your cellular connection is encrypted end-to-end between your phone and the carrier's cell tower. No one at the airport can intercept your traffic because you're not using any local network they could compromise. The signing portal's HTTPS encryption adds another layer on top. You've done this the right way.
consequence.saferAlternative: You made an excellent choice. For truly paranoid security on extremely high-value contracts, some professionals use dedicated hardware tokens or require in-person signing. But for routine business contracts, mobile data is the gold standard for security on the go.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Mobile data uses LTE/5G encryption that's far more difficult to intercept than Wi-Fi. Combined with the HTTPS encryption of the signing portal, your credentials and the signed document were protected by multiple layers of strong encryption. Local attackers had no opportunity to intercept.

scenes.title: Airport Portal
scenes.description: The airport's portal loads. It shows ads and asks you to accept terms. There's an option to 'Connect faster by downloading our Airport Companion app' and a 'Premium High-Speed Access' for $8.

scenes.title: Info Kiosk Confirmation
scenes.description: After waiting 10 minutes (your deadline is now 35 minutes away), the staff confirms: 'Our official network is MetroAirport_Free with an underscore. Be careful - we've had reports of fake networks. The SkyLounge network is only for lounge members.'

consequence.title: Attacker's Network
consequence.whatHappened: You connected to 'Airport_Free_WiFi' - a network with a suspiciously generic name and unusually strong signal. This was a portable hotspot in an attacker's backpack, set up specifically to target stressed travelers like you.
consequence.whyRisky: Airports are hunting grounds for cybercriminals because travelers are the perfect victims: stressed, tired, rushed, and often handling high-value transactions. The time pressure you felt is exactly what attackers count on. This generic-sounding network ('Airport_Free_WiFi') had a stronger signal than the real network because the attacker is sitting nearby with a high-power antenna. Your device saw it as the 'best' option and may have even auto-connected. Now, every password you type, every file you download, every email you send passes through equipment controlled by someone who wants to steal it. They specifically target business travelers because corporate credentials are worth thousands of dollars on the black market.
consequence.saferAlternative: Even under time pressure, take 30 seconds to verify the official network name. Look for posted signs, check the airport's official website using mobile data, or ask at an information desk. The real network is 'MetroAirport_Free' - notice the airport's actual name, not generic 'Airport'.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Attackers use high-gain directional antennas to broadcast a stronger signal than legitimate networks. Your device's 'auto-connect to strongest signal' feature works against you. The attacker runs specialized software to capture all traffic, harvest credentials, and inject malicious content into web pages.

cascadingEffects.effect: All your traffic passes through attacker's device
Login credentials for work systems captured
Sensitive business data exposed to competitors

consequence.title: Account Security Alert
consequence.whatHappened: You connected to 'MetroAirport-Guest' - it looked legitimate at first glance, but the real network is 'MetroAirport_Free'. The fake uses a hyphen instead of underscore, and 'Guest' instead of 'Free'. This tiny difference is the entire attack. When you tried to sign the contract, your company's security system detected suspicious login activity and locked your account.
consequence.whyRisky: This is a sophisticated attack that exploits how our brains work under stress. When you're rushed, you don't carefully read every character - you pattern-match. 'MetroAirport-Guest' looks close enough to legitimate that your tired brain accepted it. The attacker researched the airport's real network name and created a convincing variation. Now they have your corporate credentials. When they tried to use those credentials from a different location, your company's security systems detected the anomaly and locked your account to protect it. You're now locked out, you've missed your deadline, and your company's IT security team is investigating a breach.
consequence.saferAlternative: Verify network names character by character when the stakes are high. In airports, even one wrong character could mean you're connecting to an attacker's network. Better yet, use mobile data for high-stakes transactions.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Attackers research target locations to create convincing fake network names. They exploit cognitive shortcuts - we don't read every character, we recognize patterns. The captured credentials were immediately tested, triggering enterprise security systems that detected the impossible location change and locked the account.

cascadingEffects.effect: Fake network captured your work credentials
Attacker attempted to access your corporate account
Security system locked your account to protect it
You missed the contract deadline while locked out

consequence.title: Suspicious App Installed
consequence.whatHappened: Under time pressure, you installed an app from a captive portal. Even if this was a legitimate airport app, downloading software this way bypasses all the security checks that protect you in official app stores.
consequence.whyRisky: This is exactly what attackers want: a stressed traveler making quick decisions without thinking. The promise of 'faster connection' exploits your urgency. Here's the reality: legitimate airports don't require app installation for Wi-Fi access. Ever. This app, whether malicious or just poorly secured, now has whatever permissions you granted - possibly access to your contacts, location, camera, files, and keystrokes. Even if it's truly the airport's app, installing through a captive portal means you got an unverified version that could have been modified by an attacker on the network. The proper version would be in the app store with security reviews.
consequence.saferAlternative: Never install apps from captive portals. Period. If an airport truly has an app you want, download it from your device's official app store before your trip, not in a rushed moment at the gate. The 'faster connection' promise isn't worth device compromise.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Apps distributed outside official stores bypass security scanning and signature verification. The time pressure made you skip permission reviews - the app may have requested access to contacts, location, camera, files, and accessibility services. Malicious apps installed this way can record keystrokes, capture screens, and persist through device restarts.

consequence.title: Reasonable Security
consequence.whatHappened: You signed the contract while connected to the premium airport network. Paying for premium access typically provides better network isolation and sometimes encryption, making it more secure than the free open network.
consequence.whyRisky: This was a reasonable choice given the time pressure. Premium airport networks often have better security practices than free networks, and the payment barrier reduces casual attackers. Combined with the HTTPS encryption of the signing portal, your transaction had decent protection. The remaining risk is that you're still on shared infrastructure, but premium networks are less targeted than free ones.
consequence.saferAlternative: For maximum security on legal documents, mobile data or VPN would be ideal. But the premium network was a practical choice that balanced security with your deadline pressure. You recognized that not all networks are equal.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Premium networks often implement client isolation, preventing other users from seeing your traffic even on the same network. Combined with HTTPS, this provides reasonable protection. The $8 payment also creates a barrier that deters opportunistic attackers who prefer free networks with more targets.

scenes.description: You're on the free airport network without VPN. The contract deadline is in 25 minutes.

scenes.title: Unprotected Signature
scenes.description: You signed the contract on the open network...

consequence.title: High-Risk Legal Action
consequence.whatHappened: You signed a legally binding document on an open airport network. The signing portal used HTTPS, but you've still exposed yourself to sophisticated attacks that specifically target business travelers.
consequence.whyRisky: Digital signatures are serious business - they create legal obligations equivalent to your handwritten signature. Here's why this was risky: Airport networks are specifically targeted by corporate espionage groups because they know travelers sign contracts, access financial systems, and share sensitive documents. An attacker could attempt session hijacking (taking over your authenticated session), DNS spoofing (redirecting you to a fake signing portal), or credential capture. Even if the attack fails, you've performed a high-value legal transaction in a hostile environment. If something goes wrong with this contract later, you'll wonder whether the network was compromised.
consequence.saferAlternative: For legally binding documents, use mobile data or a VPN without exception. If neither is available, call the client to request a deadline extension. Most clients appreciate security-conscious partners - it shows you'll protect their interests too.
consequence.technicalExplanation: While HTTPS encrypts the signing session, attacks like SSL stripping, malicious proxy configurations, or certificate spoofing could potentially expose authentication tokens. Airports are known hunting grounds for Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) groups targeting corporate espionage.

consequence.title: Secure Under Pressure
consequence.whatHappened: Despite the deadline stress, you took the extra minute to enable VPN protection before signing the contract. This significantly reduced your exposure to network-based attacks.
consequence.whyRisky: You made the right call. That extra minute to enable VPN could be the difference between a secure contract signing and a compromised corporate account. The VPN encrypts all traffic before it touches the airport network, blocking all local network attacks. Anyone monitoring the airport Wi-Fi sees only encrypted traffic going to a VPN server - they can't tell you're signing a contract, can't intercept your credentials, and can't tamper with the transaction.
consequence.saferAlternative: This was a good decision. For maximum security on legal documents, mobile data remains the gold standard since it bypasses local networks entirely. But VPN on public Wi-Fi is a practical, effective choice that provides strong protection.
consequence.technicalExplanation: VPN encryption wraps your entire signing session in an encrypted tunnel. The airport network sees only encrypted packets going to your VPN provider's IP address. Session hijacking, DNS spoofing, and traffic analysis become impossible for local attackers.

consequence.title: Professional Judgment
consequence.whatHappened: You called the client to explain your situation and requested a deadline extension. They appreciated your honesty about security concerns and agreed to extend by 4 hours until you reach a secure network.
consequence.whyRisky: This was an excellent decision that shows mature professional judgment. It took courage to ask for an extension under pressure, but you recognized that the risk to both parties wasn't worth the time savings. Here's the hidden benefit: by explaining your security concerns, you've actually strengthened the client relationship. They now know you take information security seriously, which matters when you're handling their sensitive contract. A partner who cuts corners on their own security might cut corners on client security too.
consequence.saferAlternative: You made the optimal choice for a high-stakes legal transaction. Explaining security concerns to clients demonstrates professionalism and protects both parties. The four-hour delay is nothing compared to the potential fallout from a compromised contract signing.
consequence.technicalExplanation: By postponing the transaction, you eliminated all network-based attack vectors entirely. For legally binding documents with significant financial implications, this 'zero risk' approach is often the wisest choice. The 'attack surface' was reduced to zero.

scenes.title: Scenario Complete
scenes.description: You've completed the Airport Rush scenario! This was the most challenging test of your judgment under pressure.
